Authors:
Erwan DELRIEU-TROTTIN, Laura Brosseau-Acquaviva, Stefano
Mona, Valentina Neglia, Emily C Giles, Cristian Rapu-Edmunds, Pablo
Saenz-Agudelo
Title:
Understanding the origin of the most isolated endemic reef
fish fauna of the Indo-Pacific: coral reef fishes of Rapa Nui
Keywords:
endemism, coral reef fishes, neoendemism, phylogeny,
Easter Island, Motu Motiro Hiva (Salas y Gómez).
Abstract:
Aim: Understand the origin of the most isolated endemic
fish fauna of the Indo-Pacific, Easter Island (Rapa Nui), and infer
colonization routes and divergence times of the endemic coral reef fish
fauna from their closest relatives. Location: Easter Island (Rapa Nui),
Pacific Ocean. Methods: Samples of ten endemic species from Rapa Nui
were used: six small-range endemic species only present around Rapa Nui
and Motu Motiro Hiva (Salas y Gómez) (Cantherhines rapanui, Chaetodon
litus, Chromis randalli, Chrysiptera rapanui, Coris debueni, Kuhlia
nu¬ta¬bun¬da) and four southern subtropical species (i.e. large-range
endemic species; Centropyge hotumatua, Cheilodactylus plessisi,
Myripristis tiki, Pseudolabrus fuentesi). Eight different families are
represented: Chae¬to¬don¬tidae, Cheilodactylidae, Ku¬hliidae,
Holocentridae, Labridae, Monacanthidae, Pomacanthidae, Pomacentridae. We
present results of phylogenetic reconstruction based on mitochondrial (1
to 5) and nuclear (1 to 6) loci to place these endemic species in their
respective family phylogenies. Using these new calibrated phylogenetic
trees, species distribution and geological data, we inferred the
divergence times of these ten endemic fishes from their closest
relatives and compared biogeographical history estimation models to
reconstruct their ancestral geographic ranges and colonization routes
and underlying mechanisms of speciation.
